--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> This is entirely untrue. See Scott Stirling's good work in Chapter 5 of 
> _JUnit Recipes_.
> 

Sorry, I never intend to malign JUnit, while I think JUnit is a very
great framework, I got lots of ideas from JUnit.
I had missed the "JUnit Recipes", I want to read this book but seems I
can't get it in China. Anyway, I'll change the words about JUnit in
Jetif documentation.

> 
> You seem to frame this like a downside. Frameworks /should/ be light
and 
> supplemented by extension. That's what a good framework is; and not a 
> suite of tools that do everything. That's a /platform/.
> 
Yes, Frameworks should be light, but Jetif is not intended to provides
every thing. It's only provides the way to add extension more easier.
I prefer that "Keep it simple, while not too simple".

> 
> It looks like a good project; but I'd prefer you didn't malign JUnit 
> with false statements.
> 
Sorry again, I never want to malign JUnit, you have create a great
framework, I still think it's good enough for lots of people even now,
and in the future.

> Q: Why not extend JUnit with the very best data-driven suite mechanism 
> on the planet? The market would love that.
> 
I had tried to extend the JUnit, but I found that I have to rewrite
lots of classes to add desired features. It's impossible to change the
JUnit framework since lots of people used it, so I create a new framework.

> Take care.

Thanks for your opinion and comments.

Best Regards
------------
Vicky Wang
